questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe chest pain that he describes as "tearing" and radiating to his back. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest is taken and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's sudden, severe chest pain with a characteristic "tearing" quality radiating to the back, along with CT findings of an intimal flap dividing the aortic lumen into true and false channels, is classic for aortic dissection.

Aortic Dissection:

  • Aortic dissection involves a tear in the inner layer of the aortic wall, allowing blood to enter and split the layers of the aorta, forming a false lumen.
  • Clinical features:
    • Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region
    • Abdominal pain
    • Paraplegia
    • Syncope
    • Weakness
    • Hypotension or shock
  • Investigations:
    • CT angiography: Preferred for stable patients due to high sensitivity and availability.
    • Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE): Useful in unstable patients (e.g., hypotension with SBP <100 mmHg) or when CT is inconclusive, as it can be performed at the bedside.
    • MRI: Reserved for cases where CT findings are equivocal, though less practical in acute settings.
    • Chest X-ray: May show mediastinal widening (non-specific) or pleural effusion, but these are not diagnostic.
  • Signs of False Lumen:
    • Cobweb Sign: Linear structures within the false lumen.
    • Beak Sign: Sharp angle between the intimal flap and outer aortic wall, pointing toward the false lumen.

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary embolism (Option A): Typically presents with pleuritic chest pain, shortness of breath, and shows filling defects in pulmonary arteries on CT pulmonary angiogram, not an intimal flap in the aorta.

Aortic aneurysm (Option C): Refers to a focal dilation of the aorta; unless ruptured, it is often asymptomatic. It lacks the flap and double-lumen appearance seen in dissection.

Myocardial infarction (Option D): Presents with pressure-like chest pain, often with ECG changes and elevated cardiac enzymes. CT angiography can show coronary artery occlusion or wall motion abnormalities in MI, though it's not the primary diagnostic modality.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated for intermittent discomfort in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. She reports no underlying liver conditions but mentions consistent use of oral contraceptive pills over the past several years. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen is performed and is displayed below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a young female with a history of prolonged oral contraceptive use, a solitary, well-defined liver lesion on imaging is suggestive of a hepatic adenoma, a benign liver tumor that is often hormone-sensitive.

Imaging Characteristics:

  • Ultrasound: Shows a well-defined mass with varied echotexture, sometimes surrounded by a hypoechoic rim.
  • CT: Well-circumscribed lesion with arterial phase hyperenhancement and rapid washout.
  • MRI:
    • T1: Well-circumscribed lesion with arterial phase hyperenhancement and rapid washout.e
    • T2: Mildly brighter than liver
    • Out-of-phase: Signal loss if fat is present

Explanation of other options:

Hepatocellular carcinoma (Option A) usually occurs in cirrhotic livers, but can also occur in non-cirrhotic livers (e.g., in hepatitis B or aflatoxin exposure) and shows arterial phase enhancement with washout.

Metastatic infiltrates (Option B) tend to be multiple and occur in patients with known cancers, which this patient lacks.

Hemangioma (Option D) shows peripheral nodular enhancement and gradual fill-in, unlike the solid pattern here.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a several-month history of heartburn and retrosternal discomfort that worsens after meals and when lying down. He also reports a sour taste in his mouth and recent onset of mild dysphagia to solid foods. A barium swallow X-ray is performed and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of heartburn, retrosternal discomfort worsened by meals and lying down, sour taste (regurgitation), and mild dysphagia, combined with barium swallow findings of mucosal irregularity and possible erosions, is most consistent with reflux esophagitis.

Reflux Esophagitis:

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Caused by the reflux of gastric acid, pepsin, and bile salts into the esophagus.
    • These substances damage the distal esophageal mucosa, leading to inflammation and mucosal breaks.
    • Endoscopy detects mucosal breaks in approximately 30-40% of GERD patients.
  • Symptoms:
    • Heartburn
    • Retrosternal discomfort, worsened after meals and when lying down
    • Sour taste in the mouth (acid regurgitation)
    • Mild dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)
  • Barium Swallow Findings:
    • Mucosal irregularity
    • Possible erosions
    • Thickened mucosal folds
    • Shallow ulcers
    • Reflux of contrast into the esophagus
  • Management:
    • Lifestyle Modifications:
      • Weight loss
      • Avoid large meals, especially within 2-3 hours before bedtime.
    • Pharmacologic Therapy:
      • Start proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) once daily before the first meal for 8 weeks.
      • If symptoms persist, increase to twice daily dosing.
    • Surgical or Endoscopic Interventions:
      • Consider laparoscopic fundoplication or magnetic sphincter augmentation in patients with severe, refractory GERD or who are intolerant to medical therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Esophageal atresia (Option A): A congenital malformation where the esophagus ends in a blind pouch or connects abnormally to the trachea. In neonates, a plain X-ray typically shows a gasless abdomen or air in the gastrointestinal tract (if tracheoesophageal fistula is present). This condition does not present with mucosal inflammation.

Esophageal stricture (Option B): A narrowing of the esophageal lumen, often a complication of chronic reflux esophagitis, caustic ingestion, or other causes. Barium swallow shows a fixed, narrowed segment, but the primary diagnosis here is the underlying inflammation (reflux esophagitis), not the secondary stricture.

Achalasia (Option D): A motility disorder causing failure of lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, leading to progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids, regurgitation, and chest pain. Barium swallow shows a dilated esophagus with a "bird's beak" tapering at the gastroesophageal junction, not mucosal irregularity or ulcers.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is evaluated for repeated episodes of urinary tract infections and occasional difficulty in passing urine. As part of the diagnostic workup, an intravenous pyelogram (IVP) is conducted, and the resulting image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the radiographic findings?
questions.solution:
The image displays a characteristic "cobra head" appearance, which is pathognomonic for a ureterocele on IVP. This finding represents a congenital ballooning of the distal ureter at its junction with the bladder. The appearance is described as a contrast-filled outpouching within the bladder, surrounded by a thin radiolucent border corresponding to the wall of the ureterocele.

Ureterocele:

  • A congenital saccular enlargement of the terminal ureter
  • Epidemiology: Frequently observed in the pediatric population
  • Classification:
    • Intravesical (orthotopic): Entirely located within the bladder
    • Ectopic: May extend beyond the bladder and often occurs with a duplicated collecting system
  • Symptoms: Include urinary tract infections, hematuria, signs of bladder outlet obstruction, or trouble urinating
  • Imaging & Diagnosis: Most accurately diagnosed by IVP, ultrasound, or a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG)
  • Ureterocele on IVP:

Explanation of other options:

Horseshoe kidney (Option A): Involves the fusion of the lower poles of both kidneys, often associated with abnormal renal rotation. Does not present as a cystic lesion within the bladder.

Bladder tumor (Option C): Typically presents as an irregular or lobulated filling defect on imaging rather than a smooth, contrast-filled round structure.

Posterior urethral valve (Option D): Usually affects male infants and is seen on USG as a dilated posterior urethra with the "keyhole sign." It does not produce a cobra head configuration.

questions.text: A patient undergoing evaluation for prolonged unexplained fever (PUO) undergoes a chest X-ray. Based on these radiographic findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Miliary tuberculosis typically presents on chest radiographs as countless tiny nodular opacities, each measuring between 1 to 3 mm, evenly distributed throughout both lungs. This radiological pattern resembles millet seeds, hence the term "miliary."
  • This form of tuberculosis arises from hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, often in immunocompromised or elderly individuals. It is a classical etiology of pyrexia of unknown origin (PUO) and is frequently accompanied by systemic signs such as prolonged fever, significant weight loss, and night sweats.

Comparison of Chest X-ray Findings in Different Conditions:

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease. An upright chest X-ray is taken and is shown below. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be the cause of this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
• The identification of air beneath the diaphragm on upright chest or abdominal radiographs is a key sign of pneumoperitoneum, which generally arises due to perforation of a hollow gastrointestinal organ.
  • Although various causes can lead to this appearance, acute intestinal obstruction does not typically cause free intraperitoneal air unless there is progression to bowel necrosis and perforation, a complication rather than a routine manifestation of obstruction.

Free Air Under the Diaphragm (Pneumoperitoneum):

  • Free intraperitoneal air under the diaphragm suggests the escape of gas from the gastrointestinal tract into the peritoneal space, usually due to a perforated viscus. This finding is best visualized on upright imaging or CT scan.
  • Common causes include:
    • Duodenal ulcer perforation: When a peptic ulcer erodes through the wall of the stomach or duodenum, gas escapes into the peritoneal cavity, leading to pneumoperitoneum. (Option A)
    • Post-laparoscopy: Laparoscopic surgeries utilize carbon dioxide to inflate the abdominal cavity. This gas may persist postoperatively and present temporarily as free subdiaphragmatic air. (Option B)
    • Chilaiditi syndrome:This rare anatomical variant features interposition of the colon between the liver and the diaphragm, simulating free air. However, this is not due to a perforation. (Option C)

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing solid foods over the past few months. A barium swallow study is performed, and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of progressive dysphagia, along with systemic features like unintentional weight loss and reduced appetite, in conjunction with irregular stricturing and mucosal irregularity on the barium study, is highly indicative of esophageal carcinoma.

Radiological findings in Achalasia cardia and Carcinoma Esophagus:

Explanation of other options:

Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option B):Radiographically demonstrates a "corkscrew" or "rosary bead" pattern from non-coordinated contractions.

Esophageal leiomyoma (Option C): Presents as a smooth, intramural, well-defined filling defect on imaging, representing a benign tumor of smooth muscle origin.

Esophageal web (Option D): Typically shows as a thin shelf-like projection into the lumen, usually in the upper esophagus, frequently associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Reference:

Esophageal carcinoma

Achalasia

Bird beak sign (esophagus)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with high blood pressure, chest discomfort, and intermittent leg cramps during exertion. A chest X-ray is obtained and is shown below. Based on the radiographic evidence, what is the most likely cause of her hypertension?
questions.solution:
Key radiologic features, such as the "Figure of 3" sign and rib notching, in conjunction with clinical symptoms of hypertension and exertional chest pain, strongly point to coarctation of the aorta as the underlying diagnosis.

Figure of 3 Sign:

  • A distinctive radiologic contour of the aorta resembling the number "3," frequently seen in cases of aortic coarctation.
  • This appearance results from pre-stenotic dilation, indentation at the coarctation site, and post-stenotic dilation.

Radiographic Features of Coarctation of the Aorta (CoA):

Rib Notching Variants:

  • Bilateral: Seen when coarctation occurs distal to both subclavian arteries.
  • Right-sided only: When narrowing is located between the brachiocephalic trunk and left subclavian artery, or with a right-sided aortic arch.
  • Left-sided only: Suggests an aberrant right subclavian artery arising beyond the coarctation with collaterals forming on the left.

Explanation of other options:

Essential hypertension (Option B) refers to high blood pressure without any clear secondary cause and is usually diagnosed after ruling out specific etiologies. Given the abnormal X-ray findings in this patient, a secondary cause is evident.

Aortic aneurysm (Option C)present radiographically as localized widening or ballooning of the aorta, not as rib notching or Figure 3 sign.

Aorta-arteritis (Option D) seen in conditions like Takayasu arteritis, which may lead to vessel wall thickening and stenosis. However, it lacks the classic rib notching or Figure of 3 sign noted in coarctation.

Reference: Coarctation of the aorta | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org

questions.text: A patient presents with severe headache and neck stiffness. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain is obtained and is shown below. Based on this imaging finding, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT scan reveals hyperdense areas within the subarachnoid cisterns, which is a classic sign of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). This condition involves bleeding into the subarachnoid space, typically following a ruptured cerebral aneurysm or as a result of head trauma.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH):

Explanation of other options:

Meningitis (Option A): Although symptoms like headache and neck rigidity overlap, meningitis does not produce blood in the subarachnoid space. Imaging may reveal leptomeningeal enhancement on contrast studies.

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage (Option C): Blood in this condition is located within brain tissue rather than the subarachnoid space. Causes include hypertension or trauma.

Hemorrhagic stroke (Option D): While this term encompasses various forms of bleeding (including SAH), the specific CT finding of blood within the cisterns is most characteristic of subarachnoid hemorrhage, making it the more precise diagnosis.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470242/

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with a history of spinal tuberculosis presents with low-grade fever, dull back pain, and persistent flexion of the hip joint. On examination, movements at the hip are restricted and painful. CT imaging of the abdomen is taken and is shown below. Which muscle is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
• The structure labeled as "2" in the CT image corresponds to the psoas muscle, which is commonly implicated in the setting of spinal tuberculosis. The triad of low-grade fever, backache, and hip flexion contracture points toward a psoas abscess, which is often a complication of tubercular infection in the spine. This occurs when the infection spreads from the vertebral bodies into the psoas sheath, leading to the formation of a cold abscess, which may extend inferiorly.

Anatomy & Function of the Psoas Muscle:

  • The iliopsoas, consisting of the psoas major and iliacus, lies anterior to the hip joint.
  • It acts as a primary hip flexor, pulling the femur forward and assisting in stabilizing the spine.
  • The psoas originates from the lumbar spine and inserts into the lesser trochanter of the femur.

Spinal TB (Pott's Disease):

  • Spinal tuberculosis often affects the lower thoracic or upper lumbar spine in adults, and the upper thoracic region in children.
  • Infection typically spreads to adjacent vertebrae and intervertebral discs.
  • In advanced cases, vertebral collapse can cause kyphosis (gibbus deformity).
  • Cold abscess formation is common:
    • Upper spine TB: May track anteriorly into the chest wall.
    • Lower spine TB: Often leads to psoas abscess, which may extend to the groin or thigh.
  • Diagnosis involves:
    • Imaging (CT/MRI) to identify destructive spinal lesions and abscess formation.
    • Definitive confirmation by aspiration or biopsy for TB culture and histology.
  • Complications: Paraplegia, often due to cord compression by an abscess, requiring urgent surgical intervention if large.

Explanation of other options:

1 (Option A): Refers to abdominal wall musculature such as rectus abdominis and obliques. These muscles are not typically involved in psoas abscess.

3 (Option C): Likely indicates medial thigh/adductor compartment, responsible for hip adduction, not related to hip flexion or spinal TB spread.

4 (Option D): Represents the gluteal muscles, which function in hip extension and abduction, and are not typically involved in abscesses originating from spinal tuberculosis.

Reference: Tuberculosis of the spine - PMC.

questions.text: A 12-week-old infant is brought to the emergency department with fever, central cyanosis, and feeding fatigue. On auscultation, a widely split second heart sound is noted. A chest X-ray is done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

The chest X-ray demonstrates the classic "snowman" or "figure-of-eight" sign, which is highly indicative of the supracardiac type of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC), the most frequently observed form of this congenital defect.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC):

  • Pathology:
    • Pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium; instead, they drain abnormally into the right atrium, either directly or via systemic venous structures.
    • This is not a ductus-dependent cyanotic congenital heart disease.
  • Types of TAPVC:
    • Supracardiac (most common): Pulmonary veins drain via vertical vein into the superior vena cava.
    • Cardiac: Drainage into the coronary sinus or right atrium.
    • Infracardiac: Veins connect to portal or hepatic veins.
    • Mixed: Combination of the above.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Cyanosis and signs of congestive heart failure are typical.
    • Presence of atrial septal defect (ASD) often leads to a widely split second heart sound (S2).
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Supracardiac TAPVC often presents with a "snowman" silhouette on X-ray, a distinctive configuration due to the dilated vertical vein and SVC forming the "head" and the heart forming the "body."
  • Management:
    • Definitive treatment is surgical correction.
    • Prostaglandin E1 is not indicated since systemic circulation is not dependent on the ductus arteriosus

Explanation of other options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option B): Typically demonstrates a "boot-shaped heart" on X-ray due to right ventricular hypertrophy and upturned apex.

Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA) (Option C): Shows a classic "egg on a string" appearance, narrow mediastinum with globular heart.

Pericardial Effusion (Option D): Would be expected to have a globular, enlarged cardiac silhouette, sometimes referred to as a "water bottle" sign, reflecting fluid accumulation around the heart.

Reference:

Partial and Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.text: A child diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is scheduled to undergo total body irradiation (TBI) as part of the conditioning regimen before autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Which of the following cell types or tissues is most likely to be spared from significant radiation-induced damage?
questions.solution:
Neurons are mature, non-proliferating cells that exhibit high resistance to ionizing radiation. Since they do not divide, they are less prone to the DNA damage that primarily affects cells in active mitosis, which is why they are minimally impacted by total body irradiation.

According to the Law of Bergonie:

  • Radiation sensitivity increases with the rate of cell division.
  • Cells in mitosis (M phase) are the most radiosensitive.
  • S-phase cells (in DNA synthesis) are relatively more radioresistant.
  • Most radiosensitive tissue: Bone marrow (due to constant turnover).
  • Most radioresistant tissue: Central nervous system neurons (non-dividing).
  • Most radiosensitive blood cells: Lymphocytes.
  • Most radioresistant blood cell: Platelets.
  • Most radioresistant organ: Vagina.

Explanation of other options:

Spermatogonia (Option A): These cells are actively dividing germ cells, making them particularly vulnerable to radiation exposure. Damage to these can impair fertility due to disrupted spermatogenesis.

Intestinal epithelial cells (Option B): These cells line the gastrointestinal tract and renew rapidly, placing them among the most radiosensitive tissues. Radiation often causes mucosal injury and gastrointestinal symptoms.

Bone marrow/erythroid precursor cells (Option D): Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow are rapidly proliferating, especially the erythroid precursors, and are highly sensitive to radiation-induced cytotoxicity, often leading to bone marrow suppression post-irradiation.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7312565/#:~:text

questions.text: A 26-year-old male is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed road traffic accident. He is alert but complains of right-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, heart rate is 120 bpm, and respiratory rate is 40/min. There is decreased breath sound on the right side and hyperresonance on percussion. A chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The combination of clinical findings of hypotension, tachycardia, dyspnea and radiologic evidence is indicative of a traumatic right-sided pneumothorax, with features suggesting tension pneumothorax due to the patient's hemodynamic compromise. The urgent priority in this setting is prompt decompression, best achieved by tube thoracostomy to reduce intrapleural pressure and restore lung expansion.

Comparison of Normal and Pneumothorax Lungs:



Radiographic Features of Pneumothorax:

  • Appears as a radiolucent (black) area without vascular markings.
  • Lung tissue is compressed and displaced toward the hilum.
  • A distinct white pleural line may be visible, separating air from collapsed lungs.
  • Easier to identify on expiration films due to decreased lung volume, though air volume remains unchanged in the pneumothorax.

Radiological Techniques & Notes:

  • Lateral decubitus view (affected side up) helps detect minimal pneumothorax.
  • Shoot-through lateral view (horizontal beam) is helpful in supine trauma patients to detect anterior pneumothorax.
  • CT scan is the most sensitive modality and the investigation of choice for diagnosing pneumothorax.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441885/
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7390330/

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

The scan shown is from a PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography-Computed Tomography), a hybrid imaging modality that merges functional and anatomical data. It is primarily employed in oncology for identifying metabolically active tumors and precisely locating them within the body.

  • The PET component utilizes a positron-emitting radiotracer, most commonly F-18 fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG), which is taken up by tissues with high metabolic activity, such as malignancies.
  • The CT component supplies high-resolution anatomical detail through cross-sectional imaging.
  • The integration of PET and CT enhances localization and diagnostic accuracy of lesions.

Explanation of other options:

Sestamibi scan (Option C): A form of nuclear medicine imaging that uses technetium-99m for cardiac or parathyroid imaging, not full-body oncology.

Full Body MDCT (Multi-Detector CT) (Option D): Offers excellent anatomical detail and 3D reconstruction using multiple detector rows, but does not provide functional or metabolic data like PET.

Reference:

https://www.nibib.nih.gov/science-education/science-topics/nuclear-medicine#

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the outpatient clinic with a persistent swelling over the parietal region of the skull, noted since birth. The X-ray image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal collection of blood that typically manifests as a firm, clearly demarcated swelling localized over the parietal bones. Importantly, it does not extend beyond cranial suture lines. This lesion generally becomes noticeable within the first few hours postpartum, enlarging over the next 12-24 hours before stabilizing.


Explanation of other options:

Subgaleal Hemorrhage(Option A): This type of hemorrhage lies in a deeper plane and extends across suture lines. It is typically more extensive and may lead to hemodynamic instability due to significant blood loss, features not seen in this case.

Encephalocele (Option D): A neural tube defect where intracranial contents herniate through a skull defect. These are congenital and appear as sac-like protrusions, often requiring neurosurgical evaluation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with chronic abdominal pain and complaints of intermittent fever and weight loss. Urinalysis reveals sterile pyuria. A plain abdominal X-ray is taken and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

The combination of clinical symptoms (chronic pain, fever, weight loss), sterile pyuria, and radiographic findings points strongly toward putty kidney, a hallmark of end-stage renal tuberculosis. This condition is characterized by a shrunken, non-functioning kidney that undergoes dystrophic calcification due to chronic TB damage.

Calcifications in the Kidney:




Explanation of other options:

Psoas calcification (Option D) typically refers to calcification within the psoas muscle or tendon, and it's usually associated with chronic inflammation.

Reference: Putty Kidney

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a 5-day history of high-grade fever, productive cough, and right-sided chest discomfort. On examination, crepitations are heard over the right inframammary region. A chest X-ray is taken and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms such as fever, cough, localized crepitations combined with a well-circumscribed opacity on the X-ray that obscures the right heart border, strongly suggest right middle lobe pneumonia. This type of pneumonia is often identifiable through specific radiologic features and clinical correlation.
  • Silhouette Sign refers to the loss of a normally visible anatomical soft tissue border due to an adjacent lesion with similar radiodensity (usually fluid-filled or consolidated lung).
  • It is crucial for anterior-posterior localization of thoracic pathology.

Radiographic Views:

  • PA view (posteroanterior): Identifies structures in the superoinferior and mediolateral axes.
  • Lateral view: Shows both upper lobe bronchi, right being higher than left.

Anatomy of Lung Lobes:

  • Left Lung: Contains an oblique fissure dividing it into upper and lower lobes.
  • Right Lung: Divided into three lobes by both oblique and horizontal fissures:
    • Horizontal fissure separates the right upper lobe (RUL) and right middle lobe (RML)
    • Oblique fissure separates the RML from the right lower lobe (RLL)

Silhouette Sign:

  • Absence of the depiction of an anatomic soft-tissue border.
  • Produced by an intrathoracic abnormality that touches the borders of the heart or aorta and obliterates those borders on the frontal chest radiograph.
  • The sign actually refers to the absence of a silhouette.
  • Silhouette sign helps localize airspace opacities, atelectasis, or masses in the lung.
  • Interpretation of Key Silhouette Sign Locations:

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK370/#:~
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470197/#
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/medgen/1778950
  4. https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/silhouette-sign#

choices.text: Saccular aneurysm of the distal arch
Dissecting aneurysm of the arch of the aorta

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with dull, persistent chest pain and progressive hoarseness of voice for the past month. He is a chronic smoker and has a history of untreated hypertension. On auscultation, no significant murmurs are noted. Based on the radiographic image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

  • The co-existence of chest discomfort and voice hoarseness points toward Ortner's syndrome (cardiovocal syndrome), which occurs due to compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve by a thoracic vascular lesion like an aortic aneurysm.
  • The radiograph shows a focal dilation along the aortic arch, which aligns with a saccular aneurysm rather than a dissecting or narrowed segment.

Explanation of other options:

Dissecting aneurysm of the arch of the aorta (Option B): These cases generally present with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain that may radiate to the back. Imaging usually shows a double lumen or an intimal flap, not a focal bulge.

Coarctation of the aorta (Option C): Typically diagnosed in younger individuals, it presents with upper limb hypertension, weak femoral pulses, and rib notching from collateral circulation. Imaging shows luminal narrowing, not an outpouching.

Stenosis of the aorta (Option D): Refers to narrowing of the aortic valve, not the arch. It presents with syncope, angina, and exertional dyspnea, not compressive symptoms or focal aortic changes on imaging.

questions.text: A 6-week-old male infant is brought to the emergency department with a 5-day history of progressive, projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding. Based on the radiograph provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

The radiograph reveals features of a thickened and elongated pyloric muscle, aligning with the diagnosis of CHPS. This condition leads to gastric outlet obstruction and typically presents in male infants aged 2-6 weeks.

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms: Repeated projectile, non-bilious vomiting following feeding.
    • Physical Examination: A palpable olive-shaped mass in the epigastric region and visible gastric peristalsis may be observed.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Ultrasound (preferred modality):
      • Muscle thickness >3 mm
      • Channel length >14 mm
      • Elongated pyloric canal seen measuring 10-14 mm
    • Upper GI contrast study (alternative tool):
      • Useful for classic signs of CHPS and delayed gastric emptying.

Characteristic findings of Contrast studies in CHPS:

Explanation of other options:

Annular pancreas (Option A): Though it also causes non-bilious vomiting, it is frequently associated with Down syndrome and may coexist with duodenal atresia, findings not supported by the given radiograph.

Duodenal atresia (Option C): Typically presents with bilious vomiting and a double bubble sign on imaging, which is not seen here.

Meckel's diverticulum (Option D): Most often leads to painless lower GI bleeding, rather than vomiting.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with recurrent UTIs, poor urinary stream, and failure to thrive. On the exam, he has a distended abdomen and palpable bladder. His MCU is given below. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

  • The combination of recurrent UTIs, a weak urinary stream, abdominal distension, and palpable bladder in a male child is highly indicative of posterior urethral valves (PUV), the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in boys.
  • The MCU image typically shows:
    • Dilatation of the posterior urethra
    • Thickened bladder wall
    • Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR)
  • On ultrasound, a "keyhole sign" may be visible, reflecting a distended posterior urethra along with a thick-walled bladder.
  • Management: The standard initial treatment is endoscopic valve ablation, performed via cystoscopy. This procedure removes the obstructing valves, reducing pressure on the kidneys and improving urinary outflow, thereby preventing progression to renal damage.

Explanation of other options:

Urethral reconstruction (Option B): Reserved for rare, severe cases that do not respond to cystoscopic valve ablation. It is not the initial treatment.

Intermittent catheterization (Option C): May offer temporary decompression, but does not address the anatomical obstruction, and hence is not definitive.

Bladder augmentation surgery (Option D): Typically indicated in neurogenic bladders or noncompliant, small-capacity bladders; it is not applicable to obstructive lesions like PUV.

Reference:

  1. Posterior urethral valves
  2. Keyhole sign (posterior urethral valves)

questions.text: A patient involved in a motor vehicle accident presents with back pain. Imaging is done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A Chance fracture is characteristically linked with seatbelt-type injuries and arises from a flexion-distraction mechanism. This pattern of injury typically involves disruption of the posterior spinal elements, such as spinous processes, facet joints, or the posterior ligaments, and often coexists with intra-abdominal trauma.
  • Radiographically, this fracture is recognized by a horizontal fracture line passing through the vertebral structures posteriorly, often involving both bony and ligamentous components.

Explanation of other options:

Compression Fracture (Option A): Involves the anterior portion of the vertebral body collapsing, producing a wedge-shaped vertebra, but the posterior height remains intact.


Burst Fracture (Option B): Caused by axial loading, this injury leads to the vertebral body breaking into multiple fragments, which may be displaced into the spinal canal, increasing the risk of neurologic injury.


Impacted fracture (Option D): Seen when bone fragments are driven into one another, producing increased density at the fracture site. A typical example includes impacted femoral neck fractures, rather than spinal injuries.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with progressive vision loss. MRI is taken and is shown below. Which visual field defect is most likely present?
questions.solution:
• The MRI demonstrates a suprasellar mass consistent with craniopharyngioma, a tumor known to impinge on the optic chiasm. This anatomical location is where the nasal fibers from both eyes decussate, and these fibers are responsible for perceiving the temporal fields of vision.
  • Therefore, compression at this point classically results in a bitemporal hemianopic field defect, where vision is lost in the outer (temporal) halves of both visual fields.

Craniopharyngioma Characteristics:

  • Originates from embryonic remnants of Rathke's pouch or the craniopharyngeal duct.
  • Pediatric cases usually show the adenomatous subtype:
    • Predominantly cystic
    • Lobulated and multiloculated
    • Frequently calcified with a small solid enhancing component
  • Adults typically develop the papillary subtype:
    • Mostly solid in nature
    • Rarely calcified

Explanation of other options:

Altitudinal defect (Option A): Generally occurs with ischemic optic neuropathy or vascular occlusions, affecting either the upper or lower half of the visual field, not commonly caused by chiasmal compression.

Inferior arcuate scotoma (Option C): A pattern more typical of glaucoma, involving arcuate field loss, often in the superior or inferior portions, not across both temporal fields.

Bjerrum scotoma (Option D): Another glaucomatous defect, it manifests as a paracentral scotoma that follows the nerve fiber layer rather than aligning with chiasmal compression patterns.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents with fever and cough. His chest X-ray shows an air bronchogram sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of air bronchograms within a radiopaque lung region is a hallmark indicator of pulmonary consolidation.

Air bronchogram:

  • Represents air-filled bronchi visible against opaque, fluid-filled alveoli.
  • Significance:
    • Indicates patency of proximal airways.
    • Suggests evacuation of alveolar air due to:
      • Absorption (atelectasis).
      • Replacement (e.g., pneumonia).
      • Or a combination of these processes.
  • Persistence of gas in the bronchi indicates patency of proximal airways.
  • Seen in pulmonary parenchymal lesions and absent in extrapulmonary processes such as pleural effusion. (Option A)
  • Seen in:
    • Pulmonary consolidation (Option B)
    • Pulmonary edema: Especially with alveolar edema
    • Non-obstructive atelectasis
    • Severe interstitial lung disease
    • Neoplasms: Adenocarcinoma; Pulmonary lymphoma
    • Pulmonary infarct
    • Pulmonary hemorrhage

  • Notably, when air bronchograms persist despite antibiotic treatment, this should raise concern for malignancy. Further evaluation via CT and biopsy may be warranted in such cases.

Explanation of other options:

Pleural effusion (Option A): Manifests as fluid blunting the costophrenic angles or as a meniscus-shaped opacity, but does not show air bronchograms as the abnormality lies outside the lung parenchyma.

Hilar lymphadenopathy (Option C): Appears as rounded or lobulated opacities in the hilar region, representing enlarged lymph nodes, not associated with the air bronchogram pattern.

Bronchiectasis (Option D): Usually identified by tram-track signs or ring shadows from dilated airways. While it can coexist with consolidation, air bronchograms are more characteristic of acute alveolar filling processes rather than chronic airway dilation.

questions.text: A trauma patient undergoes a FAST scan. The ultrasound image is shown below. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
• A positive FAST scan indicates the presence of free intraperitoneal fluid, which most commonly represents hemoperitoneum in trauma patients.
  • This is typically visualized as anechoic (black) areas, especially in Morison's pouch (the hepatorenal recess), one of the first locations where fluid accumulates in the supine position.
  • This sonographic finding is significant because it suggests internal bleeding, frequently seen in blunt abdominal trauma cases.

Explanation of other options:

Negative FAST (Option B): Implies a normal study, with no evidence of free fluid or organ injury. It does not support active intra-abdominal hemorrhage.

Equivocal FAST (Option C): Describes findings that are uncertain or borderline, necessitating additional imaging, such as a CT scan, to make a definitive diagnosis.

Pneumoperitoneum (Option D): Refers to free air in the peritoneal cavity, often from visceral perforation. While ultrasound can sometimes detect free air, it is not the primary modality for identifying pneumoperitoneum; FAST is primarily used to assess free fluid (not gas).

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents with new-onset seizures. MRI shows multiple cystic brain lesions, one with a central dot (scolex). MR spectroscopy reveals elevated choline, alanine, and lactate peaks. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and imaging findings point strongly to neurocysticercosis (NCC), a parasitic infection of the CNS caused by Taenia solium. The presence of cystic brain lesions, especially one featuring a scolex, is characteristic. Additionally, the MR spectroscopy findings of increased choline, elevated alanine, and raised lactate support this diagnosis.

Neurocysticercosis:

  • Etiology: Infection with the larval stage of Taenia solium
  • Common Symptoms: Seizures, headaches, or focal neurological deficits
  • Stages: Vesicular, Colloidal, Granular, and Nodular-calcified
  • Key Radiologic and Spectroscopic Features:
  • Treatment: Albendazole + Steroids ± Antiepileptics

Explanation of other options:

Cerebral toxoplasmosis (Option A): Typically lacks the scolex sign and presents differently on spectroscopy, with lipid peaks rather than elevated alanine.

Cryptococcosis (Option C): Usually shows gelatinous pseudocysts, particularly in the basal ganglia, and MR spectroscopy shows low choline and high lipid, not alanine.

Multiple tuberculomas (Option D): Generally appear as solid granulomatous ring-enhancing lesions and tend to restrict diffusion, which differs from the cystic appearance and spectroscopic findings in NCC.

Reference:

  1. CNS cryptococcosis
  2. Intracranial Tuberculous Granuloma
  3. Neurotoxoplasmosis

questions.text: A 22-year-old male is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed car accident. On arrival, his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was E2 M2 V3. A non-contrast CT brain shows no abnormalities. There are no signs of skull fracture, raised intracranial pressure, or hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A GCS score of 7 (E2M2V3) reflects a severe disturbance in consciousness, and in the setting of normal CT findings, this is suggestive of a diffuse axonal injury (DAI).
  • DAI is commonly linked with traumatic brain injuries, especially following rapid acceleration-deceleration trauma like motor vehicle collisions.
  • Since CT imaging may initially appear normal in such cases, clinical suspicion remains crucial when the patient's level of consciousness is severely impaired.
Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI):
  • Nature of Injury: Primary traumatic injury due to widespread axonal shearing, usually affecting white matter tracts.
  • Mechanism: Often involves rotational acceleration/deceleration forces, frequent in high-speed car accidents.
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Altered or reduced consciousness, including coma
    • Minimal findings on initial CT, despite profound neurological impairment
    • Affects vital regions such as the reticular activating system, bilateral thalamus, and brainstem
  • Diagnostic Workup:
    • CT Scan: Might be normal or show small hemorrhages in areas like the corpus callosum or dorsolateral brainstem in advanced cases.
    • MRI: More sensitive than CT; identifies microhemorrhages and non-hemorrhagic axonal lesions in patients with persistent coma.
  • Postmortem Findings: Demonstrates disruption of axons and formation of characteristic retraction balls.
  • Prognosis: Generally poor, with high chances of lasting neurological impairment or death.

Explanation of other options:

Post-concussion syndrome (option B): Unlikely here, as this condition follows a mild TBI and typically arises days to weeks after the event. It presents with symptoms such as headache, dizziness, and cognitive complaints, not an acute coma.

Extradural haemorrhage (option C): Usually appears on CT as a lens-shaped (biconvex), hyperdense bleed, often associated with skull fractures, findings not present in this patient.

Herniation of brain (option D): Would show midline shift or compression of brain structures on CT and is often accompanied by signs like dilated pupils or abnormal posturing, which are not described in this case.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with confusion, constipation, and headache. Laboratory findings reveal serum calcium of 13.1 mg/dL and elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP). Primary hyperparathyroidism is suspected. Which imaging modality is preferred to localize the suspected lesion?
questions.solution:
• The Tc-99m Sestamibi scan is the most reliable imaging tool for identifying parathyroid adenomas or hyperplastic glands in the setting of primary hyperparathyroidism. This nuclear scan detects radiotracer uptake in overactive parathyroid tissue, helping in both diagnosis and surgical planning.
  • The combination of elevated serum calcium and ALP supports the clinical suspicion of a parathyroid disorder.

Radiological features of Primary Hyperparathyroidism:


Explanation of other options:

MRI (option A): While helpful in certain cases when other imaging is inconclusive, it is not the first-line tool for evaluating suspected parathyroid adenomas.

FDG PET (option B): This scan is mainly used in the oncologic setting, for detecting cancers or metastases, not routinely for parathyroid localization.

CT (option C): Although CT may assist in visualizing adenomas, it is less sensitive compared to sestamibi scans and not typically preferred as the initial investigation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man from an endemic region presents with vague upper abdominal discomfort. A non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hydatid cyst, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, often presents with characteristic findings on imaging, especially in later or inactive stages.
  • Non-contrast CT scans may demonstrate peripheral or complete calcification of the cyst wall, a hallmark of chronic or inactive hydatid infection.
  • Key imaging signs of hepatic hydatid cysts include:
    • Well-defined round or oval lesions
    • Peripheral or curvilinear calcifications
    • Specific patterns such as the "water-lily sign" or daughter cysts, which are more readily visible on ultrasound or MRI
  • This condition is endemic in several parts of the world, and diagnosis is strongly supported by both clinical history and imaging.

WHO Classification of Hydatid Cysts (Cystic Echinococcosis):

  • This staging system is based on ultrasound appearances, aiding diagnosis and therapeutic decision-making.

Imaging:

  • Ultrasound: First-line tool for assessing hydatid disease; best for visualizing daughter cysts, membranes, and internal contents.
  • CT and MRI: Useful for identifying calcification, complications like rupture or infection, and for pre-surgical planning.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatocellular carcinoma (Option A): Typically shows hypervascular lesions on contrast studies; calcification is rare and not a defining feature.

Fibronodular hyperplasia (Option B): A benign liver lesion usually diagnosed via MRI with central scar; it lacks calcifications or cystic changes.

Liver abscess (Option C): Usually presents as a fluid collection with surrounding inflammation; calcification is not a common feature and the clinical presentation is often more acute.

Reference:

Hydatid cysts - WHO classification

Gharbi

questions.text:
Which of the following are typical high-resolution CT (HRCT) findings in a patient with fungal pneumonia, such as invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
1. Interlobular septations
2. Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation
3. Pleural effusion
4. Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.solution:
• Interlobular septations (1): Seen in some cases of invasive fungal infections such as aspergillosis and mucormycosis, where inflammation or edema leads to thickened septa on HRCT.
  • Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation (2): This appearance is highly suggestive of angioinvasive fungal infections, where vascular occlusion leads to infarction and peripheral lung consolidation in a wedge shape.
  • Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities (4): A key imaging sign in invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, the "halo sign" consists of a cavitating nodule surrounded by hemorrhagic ground-glass opacity. This reflects central necrosis surrounded by hemorrhagic infiltration.
  • Pleural effusion (3): is not typically seen in fungal pneumonias. It is more characteristic of bacterial infections or empyema, making it an uncommon feature in cases like invasive aspergillosis.

Reference:

  1. Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. Reversed Halo or Atoll Sign and Bird's Nest Sign (Vogelnest)

questions.text: A young child presents to the emergency department with sudden onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray is obtained. What is the most likely object?
questions.solution:
• Button batteries are a critical emergency when aspirated or ingested by children due to the risk of rapid tissue damage.
  • On chest X-ray, they can be identified by a distinct double ring or halo sign, caused by the metallic outer rim and inner core.
  • They pose a high risk of complications, such as mucosal erosion, chemical burns, and potential perforation, making immediate identification and removal crucial.

Radiological Features of Foreign Body Ingestion


Explanation of other options:

Coin (Option B): While coins can appear as round opacities on X-rays, they lack the characteristic double ring sign seen with button batteries. Though they may obstruct the airway or esophagus, they are generally less dangerous than batteries.

Ball (Option C): Small balls may be aspirated, but their X-ray appearance is not specific and doesn't resemble the layered look of a button battery. They don't pose the same risk of chemical damage.

Bottle cap (Option D): Although it can also cause airway obstruction, a bottle cap does not produce the double contour appearance typical of button batteries and is not associated with caustic injury.

Reference:

  1. Radiopaedia - Button Battery Oesophageal Impaction
  2. Esophageal foreign body - coin
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470298/

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate interventional radiological procedure for the minimally invasive treatment of an aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

  • Endovascular coiling is a minimally invasive technique commonly employed in the treatment of aneurysms, especially intracranial ones.
  • The procedure involves advancing a catheter, typically via the femoral artery, and placing tiny coils within the aneurysmal sac.
  • These coils promote clot formation within the aneurysm, thereby preventing its rupture.
  • This method is particularly favored in patients for whom open surgical repair poses increased risk such as the elderly or those with comorbid conditions.
  • Coiling is now a standard of care in many cases of aneurysm, particularly when rapid and less invasive treatment is preferred.

Management of Aneurysms

  • Coiling:
    • A primary technique for managing aneurysms in locations such as the brain or select peripheral arteries.
    • This approach facilitates thrombosis within the aneurysm sac, reducing rupture risk.
    • It can also be used in combination with stents (stent-assisted coiling) for wide-neck aneurysms.
  • Endothermal ablation: (Option B)
    • This method uses thermal energy to treat varicose veins and is not indicated for aneurysm therapy.
  • Bare stent placement: (Option C)
    • While stents are utilized in vascular interventions, bare-metal stents alone are not appropriate for aneurysms.
    • In some situations, a stent can support coiling by maintaining arterial structure, but not as standalone therapy.
  • Sclerotherapy: (Option D)
    • Primarily used for varicose veins or superficial vascular anomalies. It involves injecting a solution that causes vessel sclerosis, which is not suitable for aneurysm treatment.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with episodes of colicky abdominal pain and vomiting. An abdominal ultrasound is taken and is shown below. Which of the following radiological signs is most characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

  • The target sign (also called the "doughnut sign") is a hallmark ultrasound finding, characterized by concentric echogenic and hypoechoic rings. These rings reflect layers of the bowel involved in the pathology and are especially seen in cases of intussusception or, in some instances, small bowel ischemia.
  • On imaging, this appears as circular ring-like structures that result from telescoping of the bowel layers, indicative of intussusception

Intussusception:

  • A segment of bowel telescopes into a distal segment, often leading to obstruction and reduced blood supply.
  • It is a leading cause of acute abdomen in children under 5, while adult cases are typically secondary to an underlying lesion.
  • Clinical signs in children may include intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, a palpable abdominal mass (often sausage-shaped), and currant jelly stools (from mucosal bleeding and sloughing).
  • However, less than 20% present with all classical signs, and around 15% may not experience pain.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • Plain X-ray:
      • May show a soft tissue mass in the upper right quadrant.
      • Findings of obstruction like air-fluid levels, and absence of distal bowel gas.
    • Fluoroscopy:
      • Contrast enema is diagnostic and therapeutic.
      • Shows the classic "coiled spring" appearance

    • Ultrasound:
      • Most sensitive and preferred modality.
      • Target sign: Concentric alternating echogenic (submucosa/serosa) and hypoechoic (muscularis) rings.
      • Pseudokidney sign: Longitudinal view mimicking renal architecture.
      • Crescent-in-doughnut sign.
      • Absent blood flow in Doppler indicates ischemia: contraindication for enema.
      • Ileocolic intussusception features: larger AP diameter, thickened wall, hyperechoic core, and visible lymph nodes.
    • CT Scan:
      • Displays a "bowel-within-bowel" pattern
      • Axial views: ring-like; longitudinal views: sausage-shaped.
      • May reveal a lead point and associated mesenteric structures.

Explanation of other options:

Claw sign (option A): Although associated with intussusception, it's typically observed on barium or CT studies and refers to the curved edge of the receiving bowel enveloping the intussusceptum-not the concentric ring appearance seen in ultrasound.


Claw Sign

Coffee bean sign (option C): Seen in sigmoid volvulus; the dilated sigmoid colon loops resemble a coffee bean on imaging, not applicable in this case.


Coffee Bean Sign

Lead pipe sign (option D): Seen in chronic ulcerative colitis, where the colon loses its haustral markings, giving a smooth "lead-pipe" appearance on barium enema-not a feature of intussusception.


Lead Pipe Sign

Reference:

Intussusception

questions.text: A young male presents to the emergency department following head trauma. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is taken and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

  • An epidural hemorrhage appears on CT imaging as a biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense area that lies between the skull and the dura mater.
  • It commonly results from the rupture of the middle meningeal artery, often following trauma.
  • Important features visible on imaging include mass effect, midline shift, and sharp margins.
  • Clinically, patients may exhibit a classic lucid interval, a brief recovery of consciousness followed by rapid neurological decline if not treated promptly.

Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH) and Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH)



Explanation of other options:

Intraventricular bleed (option A): This type of hemorrhage involves bleeding into the ventricular system, seen as hyperdense areas filling the ventricles, not lens-shaped. It is not typical of a post-traumatic epidural bleed.

Subdural hemorrhage (option C): Presents as a crescentic hyperdensity, located between the dura and arachnoid mater. It has a broader and more diffuse appearance compared to the sharply defined lentiform shape of an epidural bleed.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (option D): This bleed appears in the subarachnoid space, such as the basal cisterns, sulci, or ventricles. It often results from aneurysmal rupture and shows more diffuse blood spread on imaging.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470242/

questions.text: A newborn presents with severe respiratory distress shortly after birth. A chest X-ray is taken and is shown below. Which of the following diagnoses best explains these radiologic findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

The radiograph reveals bowel loops within the right thoracic area, a shift of the mediastinum to the left, and reduced lung aeration on the affected side, these findings support a diagnosis of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH).

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH):

  • CDH involves abdominal organs herniating into the thoracic cavity due to a developmental defect in the diaphragm.
  • Types of CDH:
    • Bochdalek Hernia: Commonly arises through the posterolateral diaphragm, usually on the left.
    • Morgagni Hernia: Occurs at the anterior diaphragm near the right cardiophrenic angle.

Fig. Schematic representation of CDH

  • Radiologic Features:
    • Chest Radiograph (CXR):
      • In Bochdalek hernias, a soft tissue shadow (dome-shaped) is typically visible in the posterior thorax.
      • Gas-filled intestines or fat may be seen within the chest cavity.
      • Mediastinal structures may be shifted away from the hernia.
    • Lateral View: Helps identify herniation above the posterior costophrenic angle.
    • CT/MRI:
      • Clearly delineates herniated contents, including spleen, bowel, or kidney.
      • Essential for ruling out other differential diagnoses like cystic lung lesions.
  • Complications:
    • Hypoplastic lungs on the affected side contribute to neonatal respiratory compromise, with symptoms manifesting soon after birth.

Explanation of other options:

Intestinal obstruction (Option B): Gas-filled loops would remain in the abdomen rather than appearing in the thorax.

Pleural effusion (Option C): Typically shows fluid accumulation and blunting of costophrenic angles without the presence of bowel loops.

Pneumonia (Option D): Appears as parenchymal lung opacities and does not involve displaced abdominal contents in the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with left hip pain and an observed limitation in abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. He denies any history of trauma. On examination, he walks with a limp. The radiograph of the pelvis is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is an adolescent orthopedic condition where the femoral head displaces relative to the femoral neck at the growth plate.
  • It typically presents with non-traumatic hip pain and an altered gait.

Frog Leg Lateral View:

  • Indication: Used in the assessment of:
    • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
    • Perthes disease
  • Procedure:
    • The patient lies supine, hip flexed 30°-40°, and abducted 45°.
    • The radiograph targets the midpoint between the ASIS and pubic symphysis.
    • If done bilaterally, the positioning resembles a frog's legs.


Explanation of other options:

Perthes disease (Option B): Results from avascular necrosis of the femoral head. Early findings include joint effusion and widened joint space; later stages show femoral head collapse and reshaping.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) (Option C): Typically diagnosed in infancy, involves underdeveloped acetabulum leading to dislocation. Radiographs show poor acetabular coverage of the femoral head.

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option D): Inflammatory arthritis of the axial skeleton. Radiographs reveal bilateral sacroiliitis and bridging syndesmophytes with characteristic spinal fusion.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An x-ray was taken which showed dilated bowel loops as given in the image below. Identify the segment involved.
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

The X-ray reveals dilated loops featuring valvulae conniventes (plicae circulares), which traverse the entire width of the bowel lumen, an identifying feature of the jejunum. These folds, appearing like stacked coins or a coiled spring, are radiologically distinct for jejunal obstruction.

Radiographic Features of Intestinal Obstruction:

  • Jejunum: Displays dense valvulae conniventes, creating a stacked coin or coiled spring appearance
  • Ileum: Has sparse, less visible folds and a more featureless appearance compared to the jejunum.
  • Duodenum: Seen dilated proximally in obstructions; duodenal atresia shows the "double bubble" sign.
  • Transverse Colon: Contains haustra that do not fully cross the lumen and are spaced wider apart than jejunal folds.

Differentiating Features Between Small Bowel and Large Bowel Obstruction


Explanation of other options:

Ileum (Option B): Lacks the complete, numerous folds seen in the jejunum; doesn"t produce the stacked coin appearance.

Duodenum (Option C): A "double bubble" is typical of duodenal atresia, not seen in this image.

Transverse Colon (Option D): Characterized by haustral markings that don"t cross the lumen entirely.

questions.text: A 74-year-old male presents with complaints of significant unintentional weight loss, loss of appetite, and iron deficiency anemia. A chest X-ray is performed and shown below. Based on the clinical and radiological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

  • The patient's systemic symptoms combined with the X-ray findings of multiple, well-defined pulmonary nodules indicate metastatic spread, commonly termed cannonball metastases.
  • The presence of multiple well-defined masses, which is a hallmark of metastasis, can lead to the diagnosis of metastatic cancer.
  • These rounded lesions are typically associated with hematogenous dissemination from primary tumors like renal cell carcinoma, colorectal cancer, or choriocarcinoma.
  • The presence of iron deficiency anemia and weight loss are paraneoplastic symptoms commonly observed in patients with metastatic cancer, reinforcing the suspicion of metastatic spread, especially when no obvious primary tumor site is initially identified.

Cannonball Metastasis:



Explanation of other options:

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option A): Usually appears centrally with spiculated borders; may involve atelectasis but not multiple, well-circumscribed nodules.

Mesothelioma (Option B): Typically results in pleural thickening, effusions, and nodular pleural masses, not round intrapulmonary nodules.

Pneumoconiosis (Option D): Presents with bilateral reticulonodular patterns and fibrosis; lacks the nodular, well-defined mass pattern.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and left flank pain. A CT scan of the abdomen is performed and is shown below. Based on the imaging and clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A congenital fusion anomaly where the lower poles of both kidneys are joined, resulting in a horseshoe shape.
  • The fusion typically obstructs the normal renal ascent during development, leading to their lower-than-normal abdominal position.
  • Clinical features: Patients may experience recurrent urinary infections, pain in the flanks, or formation of renal calculi due to disturbed urinary drainage.
  • CT findings: The kidneys appear fused at the lower poles, typically forming a midline structure. This is characteristic of a horseshoe kidney.

Explanation of other options:

Polycystic kidney disease (option B): Incorrect as it features numerous cysts disrupting renal architecture. CT would reveal multiple fluid-filled cysts rather than fused poles.

Renal ectopia (option C): Incorrect since it describes abnormally located kidneys (commonly pelvic), without fusion of lower poles or central midline mass.

Hydronephrosis (option D): Incorrect as it refers to dilated calyces and renal pelvis due to urinary obstruction. It lacks the typical midline fusion seen in horseshoe kidney.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presents with complaints of difficulty in breathing and generalized fatigue. Physical examination reveals distended neck veins, a loud diastolic sound, and Kussmaul's sign. Based on the clinical and radiological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The clinical features and X-ray findings are indicative of constrictive pericarditis. This condition arises when granulation tissue formation leads to pericardial fibrosis and calcification, thereby compromising the elasticity of the pericardium and restricting diastolic ventricular filling.
  • Radiologic hallmark: Classic "egg in a cup" configuration seen on chest X-ray.
  • Best imaging test (IOC): CT scan of the chest.

Constrictive Pericarditis:

  • Pathophysiology:
    • This disorder involves progressive fibrotic changes and calcification in the pericardium, sometimes involving the myocardium, limiting cardiac motion and reducing filling capacity.
    • This results in elevated atrial pressures and typically leads to:
      • Atrial enlargement and hypertrophy
      • High incidence of atrial fibrillation
      • Systemic venous congestion (pulmonary involvement is usually absent)

Explanation of other options:

Bronchial asthma (Option B): Typically shows signs of hyperinflation, thickened bronchial walls, and peribronchial cuffing on imaging.

Acute pericarditis (Option C): Presents with a flask-shaped, enlarged cardiac silhouette on imaging.

Atrial myxoma (Option D): May cause signs of cardiomegaly, enlargement of the left atrium, vascular redistribution, and a prominent pulmonary artery.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute shortness of breath and orthopnea. Chest X-ray is taken and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

  • The chest X-ray demonstrates bilateral diffuse alveolar shadowing, a hallmark feature of pulmonary edema.
  • A "bat-wing" or "butterfly" distribution of opacities radiating from the hilum with peripheral sparing is commonly observed.
  • Engorged pulmonary vasculature and Kerley B lines (horizontal septal lines) often accompany these findings.
  • In cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, an enlarged heart silhouette may be evident, indicating underlying heart failure.

Pulmonary Edema:


X Ray findings of Cardiogenic pulmonary edema:


Chest X-ray showing Batwing appearance due to Alveolar edema


Chest X-ray showing Kerley B lines, Cardiomegaly, Dilated vessels of upper lobe and mild pleural effusion.

Explanation of other options:

Hydrothorax (Option B): This refers to accumulation of serous fluid in the pleural cavity (e.g., due to CHF or cirrhosis). It presents on imaging with a meniscus-shaped opacity and blunting of the costophrenic angle, not diffuse alveolar opacities.

Pleural Effusion (Option C): Typically visualized as a uniform dense opacity with a curved upper border (meniscus sign), not central bilateral alveolar infiltrates as seen in pulmonary edema.

Pulmonary Fibrosis (Option D): Usually displays reticular interstitial markings, honeycomb lung appearance, and shrunken lung fields. These chronic findings contrast with the acute alveolar pattern of pulmonary edema.
